intro: Schoepfiopsis gibbosa, commonly known as the hairy leaf mistletoe, is a hemiparasitic plant that grows on the branches of host trees. It belongs to the family Loranthaceae and is characterized by its small, leathery leaves and small, white or yellowish flowers. The plant has a short stem with dense, woolly hairs, giving it a distinctive appearance. It produces small berries that are often eaten by birds, aiding in seed dispersal. Its botanical features make it an interesting subject for studies on parasitic plant ecology and plant-animal interactions.
